content: Did the ancient Greeks use the word "idiot" to insult people who did not participate in civic life or vote?

Yes, in ancient Greece, particularly in Athens, the term "idiotes" was used to describe someone who was not actively involved in public affairs or civic life. It was indeed somewhat pejorative, implying that such a person was self-centered and lacked the public spirit valued in democratic societies.

In Athenian democracy, active participation in the assembly and other civic duties was highly valued. Citizens who did not participate were sometimes looked down upon, and the term "idiotes" was used to label them. So, in that context, it was an insult to be called an "idiotes."
